Earlier in 2018, the second largest producer, Aurora Cannabis, bought competitor [[CanniMed]] in advance of the anticipated growth in the market and announced a plan to acquire MedReleaf.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.cbc.ca/news/business/aurora-medreleaf-pot-deal-1.4661629|title=Aurora buys MedReleaf to cement status as world's biggest cannabis company - CBC News|last=Evans|first=Pete|date=May 14, 2018|work=[[CBC News]]|access-date=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://business.financialpost.com/cannabis/our-eyes-are-on-the-global-market-aurora-acquires-medreleaf-in-largest-cannabis-deal-yet|title='Our eyes are on the global market': Aurora acquires MedReleaf in largest cannabis deal yet|last=Rendell|first=Mark|date=June 5, 2018|work=[[Financial Post]]|access-date=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|publisher=}}</ref> It would have distribution agreements in a number of countries, including Germany, Italy, Brazil, and Australia.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.thestar.com/edmonton/2018/05/14/edmontons-aurora-cannabis-buys-medreleaf-for-32-billion-becoming-largest-cannabis-producer-in-the-world.html|title=Edmonton's Aurora Cannabis buys MedReleaf for $3.2-billion, becoming 'largest cannabis producer in the world'|last=Maimann|first=Kevin|date=May 14, 2018|work=[[Toronto Star]]}}</ref>
By late September, Tilray, Inc. of [[Nanaimo]], a subsidiary of [[Privateer Holdings]] had reached a market capitalization about US$10 billion making it the third largest cannabis company in the world, after Canopy and Aurora.<ref name="auto4">{{cite web|url=https://www.cnbc.com/2018/09/24/tilray-shares-wipe-out-gains-from-last-weeks-wild-ride.html |title=Pot stock Tilray tumbles, completely wiping out gains from last week's wild surge|publisher=CNBC|date=September 24, 2018 |accessdate=September 26, 2018}}</ref>
===Craft cannabis=== Under the ''Cannabis Act'' passed in 2018, only producers licensed by the government are allowed to grow the product. As of early October 2018, there were at least 117 such licensed producers.<ref>{{cite web||url=https://www.cbc.ca/news/business/legal-cannabis-shortage-looms-1.4845816 |title=Don't delete your dealer's number yet — legal cannabis shortage looms |publisher =CBC News |access-date=October 27, 2018 }}</ref>
Although consolidation of the cannabis market in Canada is expected to the point where “a handful of companies will control the majority of the market”,<ref>{{cite news |last=Wood|first=David|date=October 19, 2018|title=The cannabis industry can expect more growth - and consolidation|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/cannabis/article-the-cannabis-industry-can-expect-more-growth-and-consolidation/ |work=Globe and Mail |access-date=October 21, 2018 }}</ref> many claim that there is an important need for smaller craft cannabis producers that are “more able to adapt to consumer demand”.<ref>{{cite news |last=Campbell|first=Lisa|date=July 1, 2018|title=New regulations may spark Canada’s craft cannabis revolution|url=https://www.straight.com/cannabis/1097161/new-regulations-may-spark-canadas-craft-cannabis-revolution#|work=The Georgia Straight|access-date=October 21, 2018 }}</ref> The craft cannabis industry has been compared to the craft beer industry<ref name="auto5">{{cite web |url=https://licensedproducerscanada.ca/faq/what-is-a-health-canada-licensed-producer|title=Will Craft Cannabis Growers in Canada Succeed Like Craft Brewers?|website=Licensed Producers Canada|access-date=October 21, 2018}}</ref> – smaller producers who are able to experiment more and provide a wider variety to the larger companies, which will likely try to please as many consumers as possible. However, the difference is that the relatively new rise of craft brewers in a mature market is different than craft cannabis starting at the same time as larger producers (for recreational cannabis). This will give larger producers the edge in the short term since those companies have more money.<ref>{{cite news |last=Reid|first=Sarah|date=November 15, 2017|title=Small pot producers’ plans go up in smoke|url=https://tvo.org/article/current-affairs/small-pot-producers-plans-go-up-in-smoke|work=TVO |access-date=October 21, 2018 }}</ref>
The expected buy-in for craft cannabis producers is perhaps slightly higher than craft brewers,<ref name="auto5"/> but there are other barriers to launching a craft cannabis company including the ability to market product. Cannabis marketing will be closer to tobacco marketing (which is prohibited in Canada with few limited exceptions<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.tobaccocontrollaws.org/legislation/country/canada/summary|title= Legislation by Country: Canada|website=Tobacco Control Laws|access-date=October 21, 2018}}</ref>) cannabis will be sold in plain packaging and traditional advertising such as TV commercials will be prohibited.<ref>{{cite news |last=Delacourt|first=Susan|date=June 23, 2017|title=Canadian pot ads? Think beer ads. Then think again: Delacourt|url=https://www.thestar.com/news/insight/2017/06/23/canadian-pot-ads-think-beer-ads-then-think-again-delacourt.html|work=Toronto Star|access-date=October 21, 2018 }}</ref> They will likely not even be able to mention things that could be important to the consumer such as where it’s grown (i.e., “buy local”) and if it’s organic. <ref>{{cite news |date=May 19, 2017|title=Craft cannabis growers in B.C. sound alarm over survival of sector|url=https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/british-columbia/cannabis-growers-bc-sound-alarm-over-sector-1.4670742|work=Canadian Press|access-date=October 21, 2018 }}</ref>
Further, simply selling their product may be difficult. The supply chain is still not entirely clear as it is in the beer industry, but there are ways for craft cannabis producers to sell their product through selling to other micro-processors – and potentially larger producers – or applying for a micro-processing licence themselves.<ref name="auto6">{{cite news |last=Efron|first=Sarah|date=June 22, 2018|title=Craft cannabis growers say better bud will be key to thriving in the legal market|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/business/small-business/growth/article-craft-cannabis-growers-say-better-bud-will-be-key-to-thriving-in-the/|work=Globe and Mail|access-date=October 21, 2018 }}</ref> As of the legalization date, consumers cannot sample or purchase product directly from a craft cannabis producer’s storefront as you can with craft beer or buy cannabis from a stall on the side of the road as you might from a farmer. However, [[British Columbia]]’s Public Safety Minister Mike Farnsworth said that the province wouldn’t rule out farmers selling direct to consumer.<ref>{{cite news |date=May 19, 2017|title=Craft cannabis growers in B.C. sound alarm over survival of sector|url=https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/british-columbia/cannabis-growers-bc-sound-alarm-over-sector-1.4670742|work=CBC|access-date=October 22, 2018 }}</ref>
Still, most craft cannabis producers are optimistic. One craft cannabis producer told The [[Globe and Mail]] that “I think there is a real opportunity there for small independents.”<ref name="auto6"/> Craft cannabis producers are seen by some as the “artisans of the industry”<ref>{{cite news |last=Ross|first=Andrea|date=June 24, 2018|title=First comes legal cannabis. Then, say industry insiders, will come the artisan stuff|url=https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/edmonton/alberta-cannabis-industry-craft-growers-1.4758573|work=CBC|access-date=October 22, 2018 }}</ref> who will experiment with strains, increase variety, and produce a quality product that it can sell at a premium.<ref name="auto5"/>
===Stock market volatility=== At times in 2016, and in 2017, the stock prices of some producers increased significantly as retail investors became more bullish on this segment of the market but then dropped at a later date.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/globe-investor/inside-the-market/over-50-in-3-days-why-investors-have-pushed-aurora-shares-to-new-highs/article36971073/|title=Up 60% in three days: Why investors are euphoric over Aurora Cannabis shares|last=Bouw|first=Brenda|date=November 14, 2017|work=[[The Globe and Mail]]|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=|subscription=Yes}}</ref> Between September and mid-November 2017, the typical stock cannabis producer's value increased by 54%, according to Vahan Ajamian of Beacon Securities Ltd. The share price of Canopy Growth, for example, more than doubled in price during the fall of the year, but declined in mid-November while others, such as Aurora Cannabis, increased at the same time during another volatile period.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.baystreet.ca/etfs/206/Jump-Into-the-Red-Hot-Cannabis-Market-With-This-ETF|title=Jump Into the Red Hot Cannabis Market With This ETF|last=O'Callaghan|first=Ambrose|date=November 8, 2017|website=Baystreet.ca|publisher=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/report-on-business/canopy-growth-reports-third-quarter-loss-revenue-jumps/article36970222/|title=Canopy Growth's second-quarter loss dampens marijuana stock rally|last=Pellegrini|first=Christina|date=November 14, 2017|work=[[The Globe and Mail]]|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> At the time, analysts could not predict the long-term outcome for any company.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-11-14/amid-marijuana-boom-cost-data-leave-analysts-dazed-and-confused|title=Amid Marijuana Boom, Costs Leave Analysts Dazed and Confused|last=Skerritt|first=Jen|date=November 14, 2017|website=[[Bloomberg News]]|publisher=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> A report by [[Investopedia]] on November 15 said that most cannabis stocks "can be labeled as penny stocks, so any investment may carry a significantly higher risk component."<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.investopedia.com/investing/10-canadian-marijuana-stocks/|title=10 Canadian Marijuana Stocks for Your Portfolio|last=Krishna|first=Mrinalini|date=August 3, 2018|website=[[Investopedia]]|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> One of the few Canadian marijuana stocks to trade on a major exchange ([[NASDAQ]]) and not as a penny stock was the late comer Neptune Wellness Solutions. Neptune converted its [[krill oil]] extraction plant to focus on [[Cannabidiol|CBD]] oil.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://diy-stock-investor.com/article/2018/canadas-neptune-marijuana/|title=Canada's Neptune Brings Marijuana To NASDAQ|last=|first=|date=January 10, 2018|website=DIY Stock Investor|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|accessdate=January 25, 2018}}</ref>
Market analysts Matt Bottomley and Neil Maruoka of Canaccord Genuity believe that approximately 3.8 million persons will be recreational users (presumably on a frequent basis) by 2021 with a potential for $6-billion of sales.<ref name="Skerrit"/> These analysts predicted that after legalization, there may be a "shortfall of supply in the near term" (until about 2020 perhaps) which is likely to increase the product's selling price. Their prediction was based on the government's strict standards which have resulted in few producers becoming licensed under the current system.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.huffingtonpost.ca/2016/11/30/canada-marijuana-shortage-legalization_n_13336348.html|title=Canada May Face Marijuana Shortage When It's Legalized: Canaccord|last=Tencer|first=Daniel|date=December 1, 2016|website=[[Huffington Post]]|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=December 2, 2016|quote=Canada's system for licensing marijuana producers is so tough that there likely won't be enough producers to meet demand when the federal Liberals legalize the herb}}</ref> Presumably the government will relax the qualification standards to increase the number of producers who will be licensed after cannabis is legalized for recreational use but no such plans have been revealed to date.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nhpconsulting.ca/blog/becoming-a-licensed-producer-of-medical-marijuana-in-canada/ |title=Becoming a Licensed Producer of Medical Marijuana in Canada |last=Wagner |first=Brian |date=February 4, 2016 |website=NHP Consulting |publisher=NHP Consulting |access-date=December 2, 2016 |quote=There are many unknowns about how Canada will regulate marijuana on a recreational level, but we do know that it is indeed coming.}}</ref>
Some industry observers had warned that "speculation and investor frenzy are fuelling many of the gains". Other observers pointed out that marijuana company values are high but point out that "the players have real products with real sales that are growing, unlike the many dot-com firms that fed that bubble." Nonetheless, "cannabis investors chasing the Big Green Rush are playing a dangerous game," according to Dan Nicholls, Vice President of the Marijuana Index in Los Angeles. "For a first-time investor, stocks are always risky," he said. "You can lose everything you put in, potentially, especially in a market like this."<ref>{{cite news |last=Southwick |first=Reid |date=January 27, 2017 |title=Investors dive into marijuana stocks, raising concerns about green bubble |url=http://calgaryherald.com/business/local-business/investors-dive-into-marijuana-stocks-raising-concerns-about-green-bubble |newspaper=Herald |location=Calgary |access-date=February 15, 2017}}</ref> Some market analysts voiced concern about the long-term retail price of recreational marijuana; they predict that it will decline over time after legalization because of competition and bulk sales to provincial governments. According to the CEO of Cronos Group, "It's not going to be 80 or 90 per cent margins forever. There will be a very rapid price compression" after the initial shortage of product is resolved.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://business.financialpost.com/commodities/agriculture/amid-marijuana-boom-cost-data-leave-analysts-dazed-and-confused|title='A mad green rush': As marijuana booms, analysts still hazy on impact of Canadian legalization on costs|date=November 14, 2017|publisher=}}</ref>
The probability of reducing prices as producers' costs decline due to economies of scale was confirmed by the head of the federal-provincial task force in late 2017. The government also intends to keep the net cost to the consumer adequately low so as to virtually eliminate the need for an illegal market but "not so low as to create an incentive for increased use".<ref name=autogenerated2 />
Certain investment counsellors also warned clients that marijuana stocks are very risky.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bnn.ca/video/investing-in-marijuana-stocks-a-tough-gamble-portfolio-manager~1249335|title=Investing in marijuana stocks risky: Portfolio manager|publisher=}}</ref> According to Barry Schwartz, chief investment officer at Baskin Wealth Management in Toronto, "It's not the type of investment we'd ever make" adding that he would advise anyone who asks about investing in this sector, "don't do it".<ref>{{cite web |last=Gibillini |first=Nicole |date=December 1, 2016 |title='Don't do it': Marijuana stocks 'very risky' for investors, money manager says |url=http://www.bnn.ca/don-t-do-it-marijuana-stocks-very-risky-for-investors-money-manager-warns-1.621309 |publisher=BNN/Bell Media |location=Toronto |access-date=December 2, 2016}}</ref> In spite of the significant increases in the stock prices of several cannabis producers in early November 2017, few institutional investors were buying such shares because of the uncertainty as to which would succeed and which would fail.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bnn.ca/commodities/video/cannabis-not-a-market-most-institutional-investors-want-to-get-into-says-portfolio-s-levine~1257277|title=Cannabis not a market most institutional investors want to get into, says Portfolio's Levine|publisher=}}</ref>
In November 2017, business columnist David Olive of the ''[[Toronto Star]]'' strongly recommended against investing in this industry. His rationale includes these aspects: there are too many producers for the small Canadian market ("close to 100 players"), retail prices will drop significantly, reducing margins, and the expense ratio is excessively high, so most companies will not be profitable. "Only the most risk-tolerant and speculative-minded investors should go anywhere near it," he warned.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.thestar.com/business/2017/11/17/6-reasons-an-investment-in-the-pot-industry-will-likely-go-up-in-smoke-olive.html|title=6 reasons an investment in the pot industry will likely go up in smoke: Olive|first=David|last=Olive|date=November 17, 2017|publisher=|work=Toronto Star}}</ref>
The promise of legalization boosted the price of shares in companies such as Aurora Cannabis Inc. (ACB.TO), Canopy Growth Corp. (WEED.TO 2.00%), [[Aphria Inc.]] (APH.TO), [[VIVO Cannabis]] (VIVO-V.TO) and MedReleaf Corp. (LEAF.TO) in November and December 2017.<ref>[http://mjinews.com/marijuana-index-gains-continue-pot-stock/ "Marijuana Index Gains Continue As Pot Stocks Anticipate Prohibition Repeal"], ''MJI News''.</ref> A market analyst explained that the confidence was based on the fact that legal marijuana will not be more expensive, with tax included, than the black market product; this should ensure a sizeable market for producers.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bnn.ca/marijuana-stocks-rally-following-ottawa-s-proposed-dollar-a-gram-tax-1.912096|title=Marijuana stocks rally following Ottawa's proposed dollar-a-gram tax|date=November 10, 2017|publisher=BNN}}</ref> Advertising will probably be used to boost sales. The federal task force had recommended that restrictions on ad content should be similar to those for tobacco ads, extremely stringent. The cannabis producers' lobby group, however, was proposing the gentler restrictions that apply to alcohol producers: not to appeal to youth and to promote only the brand, not the recreational use of the product.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.ctvnews.ca/business/marijuana-producers-want-advertising-rules-akin-to-alcohol-not-cigarettes-1.3674405|title=Marijuana producers want advertising rules akin to alcohol, not cigarettes|date=November 12, 2017|publisher=CTV News}}</ref>
As the stock markets approached the year-end closing in 2017, the price of major cannabis stocks surged but [[Bloomberg News]] reported that "some analysts are skeptical about demand projections, and betting against the stocks is difficult to do" because there was "almost no stock left to short, and some investors who have taken short positions in the market have lost money", quoting Ihor Dusaniwsky of S3 Partners (investment analysts) in New York.<ref name=autogenerated2 /> The BCMI Cannabis Report<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bnn.ca/video/marijuana-stocks-pull-back-from-peak-is-this-a-concern-for-investors~1029855|title=Video - BNN - Business News Network|website=BNN}}</ref> warned that the boom could "end badly", with the bubble bursting as other industries' "manias" had burst in the past.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-12-14/why-it-s-so-difficult-to-bet-against-canada-s-marijuana-boom|title=Why It's So Hard to Bet Against Canada's Marijuana Boom|date=December 14, 2017|publisher=|via=www.bloomberg.com}}</ref>
====Developments in 2018==== {{Update section|date=September 2018}} On January 4, 2018, a plunge in prices was being reported by Bloomberg.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://business.financialpost.com/investing/pot-stocks-plunge-on-report-that-u-s-is-axing-policy-that-lets-legal-marijuana-flourish|title=Pot stocks plunge as Trump administration moves to weaken marijuana legalization movement|date=January 4, 2018|publisher=}}</ref> An update by [[Forbes]] in mid-July 2018 indicated that year to date, the Canadian Marijuana (stock) Index had declined by 19.1%, but had gained 132% over the previous year.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/alanjbrochstein/2018/07/14/canadian-cannabis-stocks-weighed-down-by-capital-raises-and-new-issues/#5f9b42fd4a4a|title=Canadian Cannabis Stocks Weighed Down By Capital Raises And New Issues|date=July 14, 2018|publisher=Forbes}}</ref>
In August 2018, [[Constellation Brands]] (a beer, wine and spirits producer) announced that it would invest an additional C$5 billion (US$3.8 billion) in Canopy Growth.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.thestar.com/news/cannabis/2018/08/15/constellation-brands-invests-5b-to-boost-stake-in-pot-producer-canopy-growth.html|title=Constellation Brands invests $5B to boost stake in pot producer Canopy Growth - The Star|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://business.financialpost.com/cannabis/constellation-brands-spending-5-billion-to-increase-stake-in-canopy-growth|title=‘This is rocket fuel’: Constellation Brands spending $5 billion to boost stake in Canopy Growth|date=August 15, 2018|publisher=}}</ref> After the Constellation deal, the market value of Canopy Growth rose to US$11 billion.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://business.financialpost.com/cannabis/with-5-billion-constellation-deal-canopy-growth-is-emerging-as-the-google-of-pot|title=With $5-billion Constellation deal, Canopy Growth is emerging as the Google of pot|website=Financial Post|accessdate=August 23, 2018}}</ref>
On September 20, 2018, Tilray Inc. (TLRY:US on NASDAQ) of [[Nanaimo]], a subsidiary or [[Privateer Holdings]], became the world's largest cannabis company in terms of market capitalization,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://globalnews.ca/news/4469273/b-c-based-tilray-becomes-most-valuable-cannabis-company-after-stock-spikes-as-high-as-1600-per-cent/ |title=B.C.-based Tilray becomes most valuable cannabis company after stock spikes as high as 1,600 per cent|publisher=Bloomberg |date=September 20, 2018 |accessdate=September 21, 2018}}</ref> although 2017 revenue was only US$20 million.<ref name="auto7">{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2018-09-19/thiel-backed-fund-hits-jackpot-with-12-billion-tilray-stake |title=Peter Thiel-Backed Fund Hits the Jackpot With $12 Billion Tilray Stake|publisher=Bloomberg |date=September 19, 2018 |accessdate=September 20, 2018}}</ref> However, the share price dropped significantly over the next few days, reducing Tilray's market cap to about US$10 billion vs. the earlier $19+ billion value. <ref name="auto4"/>
In mid-September, Tilray, Inc. of [[Nanaimo]], a subsidiary of [[Privateer Holdings]] became the most valuable cannabis company in the world for a few days, after a 77% increase in its stock price.<ref name="auto7"/> Days later, that increase had been wiped out, making its market capitalization about US$10 billion vs. the earlier $19+ billion value. <ref name="auto4"/>
Experts interviewed by [[Global News]] in mid-September continued to warn about market volatility. Marc Lustig, Chairman and CEO of CannaRoyalty, for example, said this: "A lot of money has been made that is for sure, but a lot of companies are probably overvalued and it’s risky for investors. Do your research first".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://globalnews.ca/news/4460887/canada-weed-stocks-skyrocketing-investing/ |title=Canadian weed stocks are skyrocketing as legalization looms: But should you invest? |publisher=Global News |date=September 18, 2018 |accessdate=September 21, 2018}}</ref>
====Excise tax and sales tax==== {{Update section|date=September 2018}} From the early planning stages, the government indicated that the substance would be taxed. An estimate in late 2016 suggested revenues of $618 million per year from a federal tax initially, and eventually, billions, according to a report by Canada's [[Parliamentary Budget Officer]] (PBO).<ref name="Cullen"/> (A recent government estimate indicates that the illegal marijuana industry is worth $7 billion per year.<ref>{{cite news |last=Cryderman |first=Kelley |date=November 27, 2016 |title=Report on Canada's marijuana legalization due this week |url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/politics/report-on-marijuana-legalization-in-canada-due-this-week/article33065608/ |newspaper=The Globe and Mail |location=Toronto |access-date=December 2, 2016}}</ref>) The Task Force report recommended that high-potency cannabis (with a high THC content) be taxed at a higher level than the conventional product to make it less attractive to consumers.<ref name="auto2">{{cite web |url=https://ipolitics.ca/2016/12/13/set-minimum-legal-age-for-marijuana-at-18-says-task-force/ |title=Set minimum legal age for marijuana at 18, says task force |last=Duggan |first=Kyle |date=December 13, 2016 |website=iPolitics |publisher=iPolitics |access-date=December 15, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/politics/federal-task-force-advises-wide-ranging-legalization-of-recreational-marijuana/article33307322/ |title=Federal task force advises wide-ranging legalization of recreational marijuana |last=LeBlanc |first=Daniel |date=December 13, 2017 |website=The Globe and Mail |access-date=December 13, 2016 |quote=The group of experts, chaired by former Liberal minister Anne McLellan, is also recommending that high-potency products be more heavily taxed, to "discourage" their use in the general public.}}</ref>
The federal government had announced in October 2017 that its budget would include $546 million over five years to prepare the "legal framework to strictly regulate and restrict access to cannabis" and another $150 million over six years to enforce the restrictions on drug-impaired driving.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://nationalpost.com/news/politics/canadas-new-budget-numbers-show-booming-economic-growth-and-booming-spending|title=Canada's new budget numbers show booming economic growth — and booming spending|date=October 25, 2017|publisher=}}</ref> Health Canada and the Royal Canadian Mounted Police will receive a share of the funds.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-10-26/rolling-out-legal-weed-comes-with-a-high-price-tag-for-canada|title=Rolling Out Legal Weed Comes With a High Price Tag for Canada|date=October 26, 2017|publisher=|via=www.bloomberg.com}}</ref> Of this amount, municipal and indigenous police services should receive $81 million to offset the increased cost of training and resources.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://business.financialpost.com/commodities/agriculture/ottawa-proposing-legal-weed-tax-of-at-least-1-per-gram-plus-gst|title=Marijuana stocks rally as Ottawa proposes legal weed tax of at least $1 per gram, plus GST|date=November 10, 2017|publisher=}}</ref>
On November 10, 2017, the government announced that the federal excise tax, to be shared 50/50 with the provinces and territories, should not exceed $1 a gram or 10 per cent of the producer's price, whichever is higher. The government's press released did not specify higher tax on high-potency products.<ref name=Globe>Mike Hager and Carrie Tait, [https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/british-columbia/provinces-keep-lucrative-online-market-for-legal-marijuana-tothemselves/article37019186/ "Provinces to keep control of online cannabis sales"], November 18, 2017.</ref><ref name=":1" /> In December 2017, after demands from provinces for a higher percentage, a two-year agreement was signed to provide a full 75% of the tax; as well, the maximum to be taken by the federal government would be $100 million per annum, with any excess paid to the provinces and territories. The final retail price of the product will include provincial sales tax,<ref name=":0" /> ranging from 5% to 15% depending on the province.<ref name=autogenerated2 /> This arrangement will be discussed again in December 2018 to determine whether the five months of experience indicated that the 75/25 tax splitting scheme had proved to be appropriate.<ref>http://mjinews.com/finance-ministers-canadian-cannabis-tax-plan/</ref>
In provinces where householders would be permitted to grow their own plants, no tax would be charged on such cannabis.<ref>[http://www.rktaxlaw.com/marijuana-and-taxes/ "Marijuana and Taxes"], Rosen Kirshen, November 16, 2017.</ref>
== Regulation by province == {{see|Cannabis laws of Canada by province or territory}} In Canada, regulation varies province to province, though there are some general rules regarding promotion, packaging, and advertising. Adult-use cannabis can only be sold in packages of a single colour without graphics other than the logo and a health warning.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.thestar.com/business/2018/06/08/marijuana-industry-seeks-creative-ways-to-brand-product.html|title=Marijuana industry seeks 'creative ways' to brand product|last=Bissett|first=Kevin|date=June 8, 2018|work=[[Toronto Star]]|access-date=July 22, 2018|agency=[[The Canadian Press]]}}</ref> Cannabis companies in Canada will not be allowed to promote themselves through TV commercials, billboards, or glossy magazine ads, sponsor people or events, or put their names on sports and cultural facilities. To address these advertising challenges, some brands are connecting with popular media influencers like [[Gene Simmons]] and the [[Trailer Park Boys]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://ottawacitizen.com/news/local-news/pot-packages|title=Rock stars, actors getting in on Canada's race to legal weed|last=Miller|first=Jacquie|date=April 3, 2018|work=[[Ottawa Citizen]]|access-date=July 22, 2018}}</ref>
The ''Cannabis Act'' (2018) gave provinces the power to determine the method of distribution and sale and whether cannabis use will be legal inside private residence or homes if children are present in the home 12 or more hours in a day,<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.cbc.ca/news/business/provincial-marijuana-sales-retail-1.4167735|title=As provinces seek the 'right' price for pot, how it's sold could matter|last=Israel|first=Solomon|date=June 20, 2017|work=[[CBC News]]|access-date=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|publisher=}}</ref> and each will also establish the legal age for cannabis use.<ref name="auto">{{cite news|url=https://www.cbc.ca/news/politics/liberal-legal-marijuana-pot-1.4041902|title=Liberals to announce marijuana will be legal by July 1, 2018|last=Cochrane|first=David|date=March 26, 2017|work=[[CBC News]]|access-date=March 28, 2017|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref> An [[Excise Tax|excise tax]] will be levied, to be shared with the provinces and territories.<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/edmonton/pot-joe-ceci-cannabis-finance-ministers-excise-taxes-1.4443836|title=New cannabis deal an improvement but legal pot won't be a revenue generator, Alberta finance minister predicts|last=Bellefontaine|first=Michelle|date=December 11, 2017|work=[[CBC News]]|access-date=}}</ref> According to the federal government, estimated annual sales will be $4 billion (US $3.2b).<ref name="autogenerated2">{{cite news|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2018-01-02/taxes-could-help-canada-keep-its-legal-marijuana-prices-in-check|title=Taxes Could Help Canada Keep Its Legal Marijuana Prices in Check|last=Wingrove|first=Josh|date=January 2, 2018|work=[[Bloomberg News]]|access-date=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|publisher=}}</ref>
The ''Cannabis Act'' (2018) also allows householders to grow up to four cannabis plants, but [[Quebec]] and [[Manitoba]] announced that they would not permit this option.<ref name=":1">{{Cite news|url=https://globalnews.ca/news/3867467/marijuana-legalization-canada-progress/|title=Just months away, here's how pot legalization is shaping up in Canada|last=Paperny|first=Anna Mehler|date=November 17, 2017|work=[[Global News]]|access-date=|agency=[[Reuters]]|last2=Saminather|first2=Nichola}}</ref> [[New Brunswick]] is specifying indoor growing only in a separate locked space, but will also allow outdoor growing for plants that are up to 1.52m (5 feet) high.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://globalnews.ca/news/4238754/quebec-ban-marijuana-home-grows/|title=Why marijuana legalization will likely include bans on home grows|last=Cain|first=Patrick|date=May 29, 2018|work=[[Global News]]|access-date=}}</ref> <ref name=":3">{{Cite news|url=https://thehighinvestor.ca/2018/10/02/new-cannabis-regulations-explained-by-province/|title=New Cannabis Regulations Explained – By Province|date=October 2, 2018|work=The High Investor|access-date=October 7, 2018|language=en-US}}</ref>
Most provinces have set the minimum age to purchase and consume cannabis to 19 years old, although Alberta and Québec have set it to 18 years old in line with their alcohol and tobacco laws.<ref name=":3" />
Under the newly elected [[Coalition Avenir Québec]] government, the Deputy Minister for Health in October 2018, [[Lionel Carmant]] announced that the Government will tighten the rules on cannabis consumption, including increasing the legal age to consume to 21 from 18.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://montrealgazette.com/news/quebec/caq-wants-to-hike-legal-age-for-cannabis-to-21-by-march-minister-says|title=CAQ wants to hike legal age for cannabis to 21 by March, minister says|date=October 25, 2018|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://montreal.ctvnews.ca/cannabis-at-21-quebec-confirms-it-will-raise-age-asap-1.4148095|title=Cannabis at 21: Quebec confirms it will raise age ASAP|date=October 24, 2018|publisher=}}</ref> ====Retail distribution by province====
After it was known that the federal legislation would give provinces the power to determine the method of distribution and sale,<ref name="auto"/> Ontario announced that the [[Liquor Control Board of Ontario]] would be the sole vendor, but not through the 651 stores that sell alcoholic beverages. Entirely distinct Ontario Cannabis Store outlets would be opened in select municipalities.<ref>{{cite new|url=https://globalnews.ca/news/4074982/lcbo-ontario-cannabis-store/|title=LCBO releases logos for ‘Ontario Cannabis Store,’ and people are underwhelmed|author=Jessica Vomiero|date=10 March 2018|newspaper=Global News}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.thestar.com/news/queenspark/2017/09/08/lcbo-will-run-150-standalone-marijuana-stores-when-weed-is-legalized.html|title=LCBO to run 150 marijuana stores|first=Robert|last=Benzie|date=September 8, 2017|publisher=|work=Toronto Star}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://nationalpost.com/pmn/news-pmn/canada-news-pmn/canopy-growth-says-lcbo-pot-stores-a-good-step-toward-eliminating-black-market|title=Ontario government's marijuana monopoly could weed out craft growers|date=September 8, 2017|publisher=}}</ref> The product would also be marketed through online sales, also by the public entity.<ref name="financialpost.com"/>
In mid-August 2018 however, under the Progressive Conservative government that had been elected in the [[2018 Ontario general election]], an entirely new plan was formulated. Finance Minister [[Vic Fedeli]] and Attorney General [[Caroline Mulroney]] announced that after October 17, 2018, the provincial Ontario Cannabis Retail Corp. will handle online cannabis sales and wholesale distribution to private retailers, which are expected to be in place by April. The Corporation will market the product to the public, strictly online. After approximately April 1, 2019, retail stores will open, operated by the private sector while the Corporation will be the wholesaler; it will also continue on-line sales as previously, and it will provide an on-line age-verification system, with 19 as the minimum age. Municipalities will be allowed to opt out of sales via brick-and-mortar stores by January 19, 2019.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.canadianlawyermag.com/legalfeeds/author/alexia-kapralos/option-for-municipalities-to-opt-out-of-ontarios-retail-cannabis-plan-criticized-by-lawyers-16151/|title=Option for municipalities to opt out of Ontario's retail cannabis plan criticized by lawyers|last=Kapralos|first=Alexia|date=August 30, 2018|work=Canadian Lawyer|access-date=September 17, 2018|language=en}}</ref> The province will provide $40 million over two years to help municipalities cover the expenses related to legal recreational cannabis.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/toronto/pc-government-announcement-1.4783630|title=Ontario to allow private retailers to sell cannabis, province will handle online sales|last=Jones|first=Ryan Patrick|date=August 13, 2018|publisher=CBC News|accessdate= August 14, 2018}}</ref><ref name="auto8">{{Cite news|url=https://www.ctvnews.ca/canada/lack-of-ontario-retail-locations-poses-headwind-for-pot-industry-players-1.4112922|title=Option for municipalities to opt out of Ontario's retail cannabis plan criticized by lawyers|last=Kapralos|first=Alexia|date=September 27, 2018|work=CTV News|access-date=September 28, 2018|language=en}}</ref>
As of late August 2018, [[New Brunswick]], [[Quebec]], [[Nova Scotia]] and [[Prince Edward Island]] had decided to sell cannabis through government-owned stores, as liquor is sold. <ref name="auto9">{{cite web|title=Which provinces will get cannabis retail sales right?|publisher=Policy Options |date=August 30, 2018|url=http://policyoptions.irpp.org/magazines/august-2018/provinces-will-get-cannabis-retail-sales-right/ |accessdate=September 28, 2018}}</ref> Home-growing is not be permitted in [[Quebec]] or [[Manitoba]].<ref>{{citation|title=Quebec government reveals details of marijuana bill: Proposed law includes plans for sale, distribution and enforcement of cannabis|author=Kalina Laframboise|publisher=CBC News |date=November 16, 2017|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/montreal/quebec-marijuana-bill-2017-1.4404066}}</ref><ref name="auto8"/>
British Columbia planned to sell cannabis through some government stores but would allow private sector retail locations as well. Manitoba, [[Newfoundland and Labrador]] and [[Saskatchewan]] have decided to allow private retail sales with liquor control authorities responsible for regulating private stores. All of the provinces, except Manitoba, had some plan for online sales direct to consumers.<ref name="auto9"/> Quebec planned to open 20 stores, while Newfoundland and Labrador, New Brunswick, Nova Scotia and Prince Edward Island will have 24, 20, 12 and 4 retail locations, respectively. Saskatchewan planned to allow 51 and Alberta will allow up to 250 stores. There will be no cap on the number of private retail stores to be allowed throughout Ontario; applications will be vetted by the [[Alcohol and Gaming Commission of Ontario]] which will also inspect the shops after they open. The legislation was expected to state that producers and their affiliates will get a licence to operate only a single retail location at a production facility. "We want to make sure that the market is not dominated by one or two parties," according to Attorney General Caroline Mulroney.<ref>{{cite news|title=Ontario could see up to 1,000 private pot shops after cannabis legalization|date=September 27, 2018|url=http://www.thechronicleherald.ca/news/canada/ontario-could-see-up-to-1000-private-pot-shops-after-cannabis-legalization-245113/ |accessdate=September 28, 2018}}</ref> However, the wording of the plan left some questions that would still need to be answered.<ref name="auto8"/> Each province set its own procedures for retail sales, and these vary as to the ownership of retail stores (government or private enterprise) but all provinces decided to offer an option for on-line sales.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://potbyprovince.ca/ |title=Canada's Approach to Legalization and Regulation by Province|date=17 October 2018 |website=Pot By Province |access-date=28 October 2018}}</ref>
==Military== {{main|Cannabis and the Canadian military}} In early September 2018, the Canadian government released a directive stating that service members will be allowed to use cannabis following legalization in October, but with restrictions on use depending on the individual's duties.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/janetwburns/2018/09/11/canadas-military-green-lights-adult-cannabis-use-for-most-personnel/#2dd92e2875a3|title=Canadian Military Green-Lights Cannabis Use For Most Personnel|first=Janet|last=Burns|publisher=}}</ref> Per the new regulations, service members may use legal cannabis, but must cease usage:<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-canada-cannabis-military/canadas-military-unveils-rules-governing-troop-cannabis-use-idUSKCN1LN29V|title=Canada's military unveils rules governing troop cannabis use|first=Anna Mehler|last=Paperny|publisher=}}</ref>
* 8 hours prior to duty: all personnel * 24 hours prior to duty: anyone operating a weapon or vehicle * 28 days before duty: members involved in high-risk activities such as [[high altitude]] parachuting, operating in a [[hyperbaric]] environment, and serving on military aircraft *on international operations
==See also== {{col-begin}} {{Col-2}} * [[Cannabis in Alberta]] * [[Cannabis in British Columbia]] * [[Cannabis in Manitoba]] * [[Cannabis in New Brunswick]] * [[Cannabis in Newfoundland and Labrador]] * [[Cannabis in the Northwest Territories|Cannabis in the Northwest Territories]] * [[Cannabis in Nova Scotia]] {{col-break}} {{Col-2}} {{portal|Canada|Cannabis}} * [[Cannabis in Nunavut]] * [[Cannabis in Ontario]] * [[Cannabis in Prince Edward Island]] * [[Cannabis in Quebec]] * [[Cannabis in Saskatchewan]] * [[Cannabis in Yukon]] * [[Cannabis on Canadian Indian reserves]] {{col-end}}

'''Cytomegalic inclusion body disease''' ('''CIBD''') is a series of signs and symptoms caused by [[cytomegalovirus]] infection, [[toxoplasmosis]] or other rare infections such as [[herpes]] or [[rubella]] viruses. It can produce massive [[calcification]] of the [[central nervous system]], and often the [[renal system|kidneys]].<ref name="marquis">{{cite journal |vauthors=Marquis JR, Lee JK |title=Extensive central nervous system calcification in a stillborn male infant due to cytomegalovirus infection |journal=AJR. American Journal of Roentgenology |volume=127 |issue=4 |pages=665–7 |date=October 1976 |pmid=184717 |doi= 10.2214/ajr.127.4.665|url=http://www.ajronline.org/cgi/pmidlookup?view=long&pmid=184717 |issn= |accessdate=2008-10-17}}</ref>
Cytomegalic inclusion body disease is the most common cause of congenital abnormalities in the United States. It can also cause pneumonia and other diseases in immunocompromised patients, such as those with HIV/AIDS or recipients of organ transplants.<ref>{{cite book|title=Review of Medical Microbiology and Immunology|last=Levinson|first=Warren|edition=12th|publisher=McGraw-Hill|year=2012|isbn=978-0071774345}}</ref>
==Presentation== Various systems are affected. * CNS abnormalities – [[microcephaly]], [[intellectual disability]], [[spasticity]], [[epilepsy]], periventricular calcification * Eye – choroidoretinitis and optic atrophy * Ear – sensorineural deafness * Liver – hepatosplenomegaly and jaundice due to hepatitis * Lung – pneumonitis (interstitial pneumonitis) * Heart – myocarditis * Thrombocytopenic purpura, haemolytic anaemia * Late sequelae in individuals asymptomatic at birth – hearing defects and reduced intelligence The cells of the infected organ show intranuclear inclusion giving the nucleus classical owls eye appearance. Further tests like ELISA can be used to detect the antigen.
The cells of the infected organ show intranuclear inclusion giving the nucleus classical owls eye appearance. Further tests like ELISA can be used to detect the antigen.Virus can be grown in cell culture also.

{{about|the organisation|the song|dance4life (song)}} {{Infobox organization | name = dance4life | logo = | founded_date = 2003 | Executive director = Jael van der Heijden | location = [[Amsterdam]], [[Netherlands]] | origins = | key_people = International advisory board members are, Erica Terpstra, Vladimir Pozner, Nafis Sadik, Peter Piot, Tumi Makgabo, Rien van Gendt, Duncan Stutterheim and Eveline Aendekerk | area_served = Global | focus = [[HIV]], [[AIDS]] | method = Edutainment | revenue = | endowment = | num_employees = | owner = | Non-profit_slogan = Start dancing, stop aids | homepage = [http://www.dance4life.com/ www.dance4life.com] }} '''Dance4life''' is an international youth initiative to raise awareness and promote prevention of [[HIV/AIDS]]. ==Dance4Life == * Jael van der Heijden, [[Managing Director]]{{cite web |url= https://dance4life.com/team/ |title= Leadership |work= Dance4Life.com |accessdate= 15 October 2018}} * Anika de Groot, Director Fundraising and Communications ==History== dance4life was founded in 2003 by two international marketers - Dennis Karpes and Ilco van der Linde - who were struck by the force of the HIV pandemic. They shared a passion to use their commercial expertise to turn this problem around. They envisioned a world united in pushing back HIV and AIDS, with one message: start dancing, stop AIDS. dance4life has become an international youth movement. Its purpose is to create social change and empower young people to take action to push back HIV and AIDS. dance4life is about the belief that HIV and AIDS can and will be stopped the moment young people have the power to stand up and say no to unsafe sex. Starting in three countries, and having expanded to 30 countries in 2012, dance4life has grown and shaped into a worldwide youth movement. Since then dance4life has achieved the participation of 600,000 young teens in the "heart connection tour", 300,000 agents4change adolescents, the distribution of 3 million dance4life condoms to youth, over €3 million raised for local HIV prevention projects in the [[Global South]], and a worldwide hit known as the "[[dance4life (song)]]" anthem by [[Tiësto]] featuring [[Maxi Jazz]] between 2003 and 2006.{{cite web|url=http://www.dance4life.com/en_4life/history|title=History|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080530045703/http://www.dance4life.com/en_4life/history|archivedate=2008-05-30|df=}} It has been estimated that by the Saturday before [[World AIDS Day]] 2014, the foundation will have created a total of one million agents4change. An agent4change is a young person who has participated in the dance4life "schools4life" and is involved in pushing back HIV and AIDS. In 2004, during the first dance4life episode, thousands of people in the [[Netherlands]], [[South Africa]] and [[Indonesia]] participated. dance4life chose a song called "Breathe Sunshine" by Dino Sofos as their official anthem. The song was also remixed by DJ [[Paul van Dyk]], released on vinyl and CD worldwide and was played by Paul van Dyk and at all the dance4life world events over the course of 2004 and 2005. {{quote box|width=30%|salign=right|quote="What I like about it is that we raise money in the western world and create awareness in the countries that get hit the hardest like Africa and Asia. The whole concept behind it is to let the whole world dance, which is a very positive message."|source=- said Tiësto to Sterling McGarvey.{{cite web |title=Tiesto Interview |url=http://music.ign.com/articles/720/720390p1.html/ |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060821094007/http://music.ign.com/articles/720/720390p1.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2006-08-21 |publisher=music.ign.com |accessdate=2008-04-17 |df= }} }} As of May 2006, [[Disc jockey|DJ]] [[Tiësto]] is the official worldwide ambassador for the dance4life foundation. He recorded a track with [[Maxi Jazz]] (of [[Faithless]]) of the [[dance4life (song)|same name]]. The song peaked for five weeks in the Dutch [[Dutch Top 40|Singles Chart]], peaking at number five in Belgium, six in Finland and also charting in the UK and Germany. In 2009 supermodel Doutzen Kroes became an ambassador. She visited dance4life projects in Tanzania, The United States, The Netherlands and Thailand and raised money through auctions for dance4life. ==Schools4Life== Schools4life has nothing to do with books, preaching or homework, instead it is about dance, music, media, events, drumming, videos and taking the responsibility of living a life under protection. Using the language of people younger than 25 years the school begins with the Heart Connection Tour in which each school is visited by the dance4life tour team; The team is composed of dancers, musicians, [[peer educator]]s and young people living with [[HIV]]. Students later take the responsibility by participating in "skills4life" which deals with the teaching of what is HIV and what it does to your body, other topics are its prevention, sexuality, drug abuse, and the rights of the teens, communication, and decision making. "Act4life" stands for taking action as a volunteer, fund raising or the spreading of the information as it is important to make people aware. To conclude schools4life, at the dance4life event which takes place every two years on the Saturday before [[World AIDS Day]], on November 29, 2008 the agents of change are present at the event live or via satellite.{{cite web|url=http://www.dance4life.com/en_4life/about|title=Schools4Life|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080920001413/http://www.dance4life.com/en_4life/about|archivedate=2008-09-20|df=}} ==Ambassadors== * [[Doutzen Kroes]], international dance4life ambassador * [[Tiësto]], international dance4life ambassador
{{Col-begin}} {{Col-2}} * Alexander Shelley, dance4life [[Germany]] * Alexey Vorobyov, dance4life [[Russia]] * [[Aly & Fila]], dance4life [[Egypt]] * {{Interlanguage link multi|Benjamin Bates (DJ)|nl|3=Benjamin Bates|lt=Benjamin Bates}}, dance4life [[Netherlands]] * DJ Black Coffee and SHANA, dance4life [[South Africa]] * Dj Willber Luno Phoenix, dance4life [[Bangladesh]] * Black Mango Music, dance4life [[South Africa]] * Dare Art Alade, dance4life [[Nigeria]] * Don Diablo, dance4life [[Netherlands]] * Ebby Sykes, dance4life [[Tanzania]] * DJ Feel, dance4life [[Russia]] * Fid Q, dance4life [[Tanzania]] * [[Jan Kooijman]], dance4life [[Netherlands]] * Jesse Voorn, dance4life [[Netherlands]] * [[DJ Jimmy Jatt]], dance4life [[Nigeria]] * [[Kaffy]] and her [[Imagneto Dance Company|Imagneto Dance Group]], dance4life [[Nigeria]] * Katung, Maureen and Gideon, dance4life [[Nigeria]] * [[DJ Khaled]] Abdel Rahman, dance4life [[Egypt]] {{Col-2}} * [[Marco V]], dance4life [[Netherlands]] * [[Maxi Jazz]], dance4life [[Netherlands]] * Metis, dance4life [[UK]] * Nikkie Plessen, dance4life [[Netherlands]] * The Partysquad, dance4life [[Netherlands]] * [[Sander van Doorn]], dance4life [[Netherlands]] * [[Sied van Riel]], dance4life [[Netherlands]] * Sandrien, dance4life [[Netherlands]] * Stella Damascus, dance4life [[Nigeria]] * [[Tim Westwood]], dance4life [[UK]] * Unique Sisters, dance4life [[Tanzania]] * [[Vladimir Posner]], dance4life [[Russia]] * Wust El Bala, dance4life [[Egypt]] * [[Yousra]], dance4life [[Egypt]] * [[Zahi Hawass]], dance4life [[Egypt]] * Zoë Xenia, dance4life [[Netherlands]] * Zolani Mkiva, dance4life [[South Africa]] * Ana Stanic, dance4life [[Serbia]] {{Col-end}} ==NCOs== *Barbados - [http://www.Dance4LifeBarbados.com Dance4Life Barbados] has been a registered not-for profit organisation since 2013 and is its own NCO. It was established in 2009 by its original NCO - [http://www.aidincorporated.org Associates for International Development] to empower and strengthen leadership and social development participation of young people in Barbados, by co-ordinating and implementing the Dance4Life empowerment model in Barbados to ultimately, through cross-fertilisation of skills and transference of lessons learned, extend to the wider Caribbean. * Germany - Dance4Life Deutschland e.V., which works closely with organisations such as Deutsche Aids Hilfe e.V. and in some federal states, Deutsche Stiftung Weltbevölkerung. Dance4Life Deutschland e.V. is supported by SV [[Werder Bremen]], [[Die Deutsche Kammerphilharmonie Bremen]], [[Royston Maldoom]]. * Ireland - [[Irish Family Planning Association]] (IFPA) who work close with the Sexual Health Centre in [[Cork (city)|Cork]]. [[Irish Aid]] is the chief funder, the organisation in [[Ireland]] is also supported financially by the [[International Planned Parenthood Federation]] (IPPF), [[United Nations Population Fund]] (UNFPA) and Durex Ireland. * Kenya - Africa Alive! is the Kenyan NCO, which educates and provides the youth with the skills necessary to push back [[HIV]] and [[AIDS]]. It works in five African countries and its regional office is in [[Nairobi]], [[Kenya]]. It counts with the support from the [[Johns Hopkins University Center for Communication Programs]] (JHUCCP). * Mexico - [[United Nations Population Fund]] (UNFPA), it promotes the right of every woman, man and child to enjoy a life of health and equal opportunity. It consists of four organisations: MEXFAM, AVE de México, ELIGE, and VIVIR. * Moldova - [[ICF "AIDS Foundation East-West" (AFEW-Ukraine)|ICF "AIDS Foundation East-West" (''AFEW-Ukraine'')]] is a [[Netherlands|Dutch]] NGO in [[Eastern Europe]] and [[Central Asia]], The work began in [[Moldova]] in 2004. Dance4Life Moldova is working with many partners to make the projects successful, including: Ministry of Education and Youth; [[Ministry of Health (Moldova)|Ministry of Health]]; Country Coordination Mechanism; National AIDS Centre; Republican Dermato Venereal Dispenser; National Scientific Centre of Preventive Medicine; UNAIDS Moldova; SIDA; UCIMP TB/SIDA; NGO National Health Journalists Communication Network; Credinta Association (PLWH); Centre of Young Journalists Moldova (CTJM); Association of Young Trainers from Moldova; NGO Gender Doc M; Representation in Moldova of TV and radio company [[Mir TV|MIR]]; and radio Station [[Kiss FM Chisinau|Kiss FM]]. * Netherlands - STOP AIDS NOW! is an organisation which is a partnership between AIDS Fonds and four Dutch organisations providing international development aid. * Russia - The FOCUS-MEDIA Foundation uses [[social marketing]] techniques, education programs, and mass media campaigns based on promoting options and personal responsibility. * Sierra Leone - The National Concept Owner is Student Partnerships Worldwide that recruits and trains young adults (aged 18–28) as volunteer Peer Educators, to lead programmes addressing urgent health and environmental issues in [[Africa]] and [[Asia]]. * South Africa - Dance4Life South Africa is a registered not-for profit [[South African company law#Non-profit companies|Section 21]] Company that has been established especially to co-ordinate, develop and organise the Dance4Life concept in [[South Africa]]. The office is located in [[Durban]], [[South Africa]] and it works with organisations like God's Golden Acre, and DramAide; Companies like The Three Cities Hotel Group and Gear House support Dance4Life South Africa. * Tanzania - The National Concept Owner is Student Partnerships Worldwide that recruits and trains young adults (aged 18–28) as volunteer Peer Educators, to lead programmes addressing urgent health and environmental issues in [[Africa]] and [[Asia]]. * Turkey - UNFPA is the National Concept Owner of Dance4Life Turkey. Y-PEER, the Youth Peer Education Network launched by the UNFPA which deals with young people in broad areas of adolescent sexual and reproductive health in [[Central Europe|Central]] and [[Eastern Europe]], [[Central Asia]], the [[Middle East]], and both [[North Africa|North]] and [[East Africa]]. The Positive Living Association and the Turkish Education Association help this foundation. * Uganda - The National Concept Owner is Student Partnerships Worldwide that recruits and trains young adults (aged 18–28) as volunteer Peer Educators, to lead programmes addressing urgent health and environmental issues in [[Africa]] and [[Asia]]. * [[Dance4Life (UK)|United Kingdom]] - The National Concept Owner is Student Partnerships Worldwide that recruits and trains young adults (aged 18–28) as volunteer Peer Educators, to lead programmes addressing urgent health and environmental issues in [[Africa]] and [[Asia]]. * USA - Student Partnerships Worldwide USA is concentrated in [[Washington DC]], It works in rural communities in [[South Asia]] and [[sub-Saharan Africa]]. It work with national partners, Metro TeenAIDS (MTA) and [[Red Zebra Broadcasting|Red Zebra]]. * Vietnam - The World Population Foundation has an office in [[Hanoi]] which holds the right that sex is a free and well-considered choice for all men, women and young people in the world. It is sponsored by TRG International and [[Durex]] and partners [[Rosette (company)|Rosette]] event organising company and Thang Long Song music and dance theater. * Zambia - The National Concept Owner is Student Partnerships Worldwide that recruits and trains young adults (aged 18–28) as volunteer Peer Educators, to lead programmes addressing urgent health and environmental issues in [[Africa]] and [[Asia]]. * Zimbabwe - The National Concept Owner is Student Partnerships Worldwide that recruits and trains young adults (aged 18–28) as volunteer Peer Educators, to lead programmes addressing urgent health and environmental issues in [[Africa]] and [[Asia]]. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.dance4life.com/ dance4life international website] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20100301101807/http://www.dance4life.co.uk/ dance4life UK website] {{DEFAULTSORT:Dance4life}} [[Category:HIV/AIDS organizations]] [[Category:Medical and health organisations based in the Netherlands]] [[Category:Dance organizations]]

{{Redirect|Eat|other uses of "eat", or "EAT" as an abbreviation or acronym|EAT (disambiguation)}} {{Redirect|Feeding}} [[File:Amandines de Provence, poster by Leonetto Cappiello, 1900.jpg|thumb|288px|Amandines de Provence, poster by Leonetto Cappiello, 1900]]
'''Eating''' (also known as '''consuming''') is the [[ingestion]] of [[food]], typically to provide a heterotrophic [[organism]] with [[food energy|energy]] and to allow for [[:wikt:growth|growth]]. Animals and other [[heterotroph]]s must eat in order to survive — [[carnivore]]s eat other animals, [[herbivore]]s eat plants, [[omnivore]]s consume a mixture of both plant and animal matter, and [[detritivores]] eat [[detritus]]. Fungi digest organic matter outside their bodies as opposed to animals that digest their food inside their bodies. For humans, eating is an [[Activities of daily living|activity of daily living]]. Some individuals may limit their amount of nutritional intake. This may be a result of a lifestyle choice, due to [[hunger]] or [[famine]], as part of a [[Dieting|diet]] or as religious fasting.
==Eating practices among humans== [[File:Photo degustation.JPG|thumb|200px|Women eating biscuits in England]]
[[File:Japanese Gothic lolita.jpg|thumb|200px|A girl eating a cake]] Many homes have a large eating room or outside (in the tropics) kitchen area devoted to preparation of meals and food, and may have a [[dining room]], [[dining hall]], or another designated area for eating. Some trains have a [[dining car]].
Most societies also have [[restaurant]]s, [[food court]]s, and [[street food|food vendors]] so that people may eat when away from home, when lacking time to prepare food, or as a social occasion ([[dining club]]).<ref>John Raulston Saul (1995), "The Doubter's Companion", 155</ref> At their highest level of sophistication, these places become "theatrical spectacles of [[global cosmopolitanism]] and [[myth]]."<ref>David Grazian (2008), "On the Make: The Hustle of Urban Nightlife", 32</ref> At [[picnic]]s, [[potluck]]s, and [[food festival]]s, eating is in fact the primary purpose of a social gathering. At many social events, food and beverages are made available to attendees.
Dishware, silverware, [[drinkware]], and [[cookware]] come in a wide array of forms and sizes.
People usually have two or three meals a day regularly. [[Snack]]s of smaller amounts may be consumed between meals. Doctors in the UK, recommend three meals a day ( with between 400-600 kcal per meal),<ref name="smart">{{cite web|title=Be calorie smart 400-600-600|url=http://www.nhs.uk/Change4Life/Pages/calories.aspx|publisher=nhs.uk|accessdate=25 May 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Cut down on your calories|url=http://www.nhs.uk/Livewell/Goodfood/Pages/eat-less.aspx#you|date=15 October 2015|publisher=nhs.uk|accessdate=25 May 2017}}</ref> with four to six hours between.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Sen|first1=Debarati|title=How often should you eat?|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/life-style/health-fitness/diet/How-often-should-you-eat/articleshow/15616282.cms|accessdate=25 May 2017|work=Times of India|date=27 July 2016}}</ref> Having three well-balanced meals (thus half of the plate with vegetables,<ref>[http://www.hsph.harvard.edu/nutritionsource/what-should-you-eat/vegetables-and-fruits/ Half of plate to be filled with vegetables, according to Harvard School of Public Health]</ref> 1/4 protein food as meat, ... and 1/4 carbohydrates as pasta, rice, ...) will then account to some 1800–2000 kcal, which is the average requirement for a regular person.<ref>[http://www.iloveindia.com/nutrition/food-facts/calorie-requirement-of-body.html Calorie requirements for regular person estimated at 2000 kcal]</ref>
The issue of [[healthy eating]] has long been an important concern to individuals and cultures. Among other practices, [[fasting]], [[dieting]], and [[vegetarianism]] are all techniques employed by individuals and encouraged by societies to increase longevity and health. Some religions promote vegetarianism, considering it wrong to consume animals. Leading nutritionists believe that instead of indulging oneself in three large meals each day, it is much healthier and easier on the metabolism to eat five smaller meals each day (e.g. better digestion, easier on the lower intestine to deposit wastes; whereas larger meals are tougher on the digestive tract and may call for the use of [[laxatives]].<ref>Micheals, Jullian. "FitWatch - Free Online Calorie Counter & Diet Tracker / Weight Loss Tools and Calculators." FitWatch RSS. N.p., n.d. Web. 13 Mar. 2013.</ref> However, psychiatrists with [[Yale School of Medicine|Yale Medical School]] have found that people who suffer from [[Binge Eating Disorder]] (BED) and consume three meals per day weigh less than those who have meals that are more frequent. Eating can also be a way of making money (see [[competitive eating]]). In jurisdictions under [[sharia law]], it may be proscribed for [[Muslim]] [[adult]]s during the daylight hours of [[Ramadan]].<ref>Sharia and Social Engineering: p 143, R. Michael Feener - 2013</ref><ref>FOOD & EATING IN MEDIEVAL EUROPE - Page 73, Joel T. Rosenthal - 1998</ref><ref>Conscious Eating: Second Edition - Page 9, Gabriel Cousens, M.D. - 2009</ref>
==Development in humans== {{unreferenced section|date=July 2016}} [[File:Abell-photoblog28.jpg|thumb|Eating with [[fork]] at a restaurant ]] [[File:Hayat-02.JPG|thumb|Traditional way of eating in Uzbekistan]] [[File:Girl with chopsticks at dumpling restaurant.jpg|thumb|Girl with [[chopsticks]]]] [[File:Ethiopian food.jpg|thumb|Ethiopians eating with hands]]
Newborn babies do not eat adult foods. They survive solely on breast milk or formula.<ref>{{cite web|title=How to combine breast and bottle feeding|url=http://www.nhs.uk/Conditions/pregnancy-and-baby/Pages/combining-breast-and-bottle.aspx|publisher=nhs.uk|accessdate=5 October 2017}}</ref> Small amounts of pureed food are sometimes fed to young infants as young as two or three months old, but most infants do not eat adult food until they are between six and eight months old. Young babies eat pureed [[baby food]]s because they have few teeth and immature digestive systems. Between 8 and 12 months of age, the digestive system improves, and many babies begin eating finger foods. Their diet is still limited, however, because most babies lack molars or canines at this age, and often have a limited number of incisors. By 18 months, babies often have enough teeth and a sufficiently mature digestive system to eat the same foods as adults. Learning to eat is a messy process for children, and children often do not master neatness or eating etiquette until they are 5 or 6 years old.
===Eating positions=== {{expand section|Additional information regarding Far East, Europe and America|date=September 2011}} Eating positions vary according to the different regions of the world, as culture influences the way people eat their meals. For example, most of the Middle Eastern countries, eating while sitting on the floor is most common, and it is believed to be healthier than eating while sitting to a table.<ref>{{Cite book|title=The Middle Eastern American Experience|last=Donovan|first=Sandy|publisher=Twenty-First Century Books|year=2010|isbn=9780761363613|location=United States|pages=68}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Brito|first=Leonardo Barbosa Barreto de|last2=Ricardo|first2=Djalma Rabelo|last3=Araújo|first3=Denise Sardinha Mendes Soares de|last4=Ramos|first4=Plínio Santos|last5=Myers|first5=Jonathan|last6=Araújo|first6=Claudio Gil Soares de|date=2012-12-13|title=Ability to sit and rise from the floor as a predictor of all-cause mortality|url=http://cpr.sagepub.com/content/early/2012/12/10/2047487312471759|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130112022009/http://cpr.sagepub.com/content/early/2012/12/10/2047487312471759|dead-url=yes|archive-date=2013-01-12|journal=European Journal of Preventive Cardiology|language=en|pages=2047487312471759|doi=10.1177/2047487312471759|issn=2047-4873|pmid=23242910|volume=21}}</ref>
===Compulsive overeating=== {{main|Compulsive overeating}} Compulsive overeating, or emotional eating, is "the tendency to eat in response to negative emotions".<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Eldredge | first1 = K. L. | last2 = Agras | first2 = W. S. | year = 1994 | title = Weight and Shape Overconcern and Emotional Eating in Binge Eating Disorder | doi = 10.1002/(SICI)1098-108X(199601)19:1<73::AID-EAT9>3.0.CO;2-T | journal = International Journal of Eating Disorders | volume = 19 | issue = 1| pages = 73–82 }}</ref> Empirical studies have indicated that anxiety leads to decreased food consumption in people with normal weight and increased food consumption in the obese.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = McKenna | first1 = R. J. | year = 1972 | title = Some Effects of Anxiety Level and Food Cues on the Eating Behavior of Obese and Normal Subjects: A Comparison of Schachterian and Psychosomatic Conceptions | url = | journal = Journal of Personality and Social Psychology | volume = 22 | issue = 3| pages = 311–319 | doi=10.1037/h0032925}}</ref>
Many laboratory studies showed that overweight individuals are more emotionally reactive and are more likely to overeat when distressed than people of normal weight. Furthermore, it was consistently found that obese individuals experience negative emotions more frequently and more intensively than do normal weight persons.<ref name="Lowe">{{cite journal | last1 = Lowe | first1 = M. R. | last2 = Fisher | first2 = E. B. Jr | year = 1983 | title = Emotional Reactivity, Emotional Eating, and Obesity: A Naturalistic Study | url = | journal = Journal of Behavioral Medicine | volume = 6 | issue = 2| pages = 135–149 | doi=10.1007/bf00845377}}</ref>
The naturalistic study by Lowe and Fisher compared the emotional reactivity and emotional eating of normal and overweight female college students. The study confirmed the tendency of obese individuals to overeat, but these findings applied only to snacks, not to meals. That means that obese individuals did not tend to eat more while having meals; rather, the amount of snacks they ate between meals was greater. One possible explanation that Lowe and Fisher suggest is obese individuals often eat their meals with others and do not eat more than average due to the reduction of distress because of the presence of other people. Another possible explanation would be that obese individuals do not eat more than the others while having meals due to social desirability. Conversely, snacks are usually eaten alone.<ref name="Lowe"/>
===Hunger and satiety=== {{Further|Hunger (motivational state)}} There are many physiological mechanisms that control starting and stopping a meal. The control of food intake is a physiologically complex, motivated behavioral system. Hormones such as [[cholecystokinin]], [[bombesin]], [[neurotensin]], [[anorectic|anorectin]], [[calcitonin]], [[enterostatin]], [[leptin]] and [[corticotropin-releasing hormone]] have all been shown to suppress food intake.<ref>Geiselman, P.J. (1996). Control of food intake. A physiologically complex, motivated behavioral system. Endocrinol Metab Clin North Am. 1996 Dec;25(4):815-29.</ref><ref>https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/dispomim.cgi?id=164160&rn=1</ref>
====Initiation==== [[File:German Shepherd puppy eating out of a human hand.jpg|thumb|200px|German Shepherd puppy eating out of a human hand]] There are numerous signals given off that initiate [[hunger]]. There are environmental signals, signals from the [[gastrointestinal system]], and [[metabolism|metabolic signals]] that trigger hunger. The environmental signals come from the body’s [[senses]]. The feeling of hunger could be triggered by the smell and thought of food, the sight of a plate, or hearing someone talk about food.<ref name=Carlson>{{cite book|last=Carlson|first=Neil|title=Physiology of Behavior|year=2010|publisher=Allyn & Bacon|location=Boston, MA|pages=412–426}}</ref> The signals from the stomach are initiated by the release of the [[peptide hormone]] ghrelin. Ghrelin is a hormone that increases appetite by signaling to the brain that a person is hungry.<ref name=Ghrelin>{{cite web|last=Funai, M.D.|first=Edmund|title=Ghrelin, Hormone That Stimulates Appetite, Found To Be Higher In PWS|url=http://www.pwsausa.org/research/ghrelin.htm|accessdate=29 April 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120531141800/http://www.pwsausa.org/research/ghrelin.htm|archivedate=31 May 2012|df=}}</ref>
Environmental signals and ghrelin are not the only signals that initiate hunger, there are other metabolic signals as well. As time passes between meals, the body starts to take nutrients from long-term reservoirs.<ref name=Carlson /> When the glucose levels of cells drop (glucoprivation), the body starts to produce the feeling of hunger. The body also stimulates eating by detecting a drop in cellular lipid levels (lipoprivation).<ref name=Carlson /> Both the brain and the liver monitor the levels of metabolic fuels. The brain checks for glucoprivation on its side of the blood–brain barrier (since glucose is its fuel), while the liver monitors the rest of the body for both lipoprivation and glucoprivation.<ref name=NCBI>{{cite web|last=Berg|first=JM|title=Section 30.2Each Organ Has a Unique Metabolic Profile|url=https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK22436/|work=Biochemistry 5th Edition|publisher=W H Freeman|accessdate=29 April 2012}}</ref>
====Termination==== There are short-term signals of satiety that arise from the head, the stomach, the intestines, and the liver. The long-term signals of satiety come from [[adipose tissue]].<ref name=Carlson /> The taste and odor of food can contribute to short-term satiety, allowing the body to learn when to stop eating. The stomach contains receptors to allow us to know when we are full. The intestines also contain receptors that send satiety signals to the brain. The hormone [[cholecystokinin]] is secreted by the [[duodenum]], and it controls the rate at which the stomach is emptied.<ref name=CCK>{{cite journal|last=Little|first=TJ|title=Role of cholecystokinin in appetite control and body weight regulation.|work=Obesity Reviews|author2=Horowitz, M |author3=Feinle-Bisset, C.|pmid=16246215|doi=10.1111/j.1467-789X.2005.00212.x|volume=6|pages=297–306}}</ref> This hormone is thought to be a satiety signal to the brain. [[Peptide YY]] 3-36 is a hormone released by the [[small intestine]] and it is also used as a satiety signal to the brain.<ref name="Peptide YY 3-36">{{cite journal|last=Degen|first=L|title=Effect of peptide YY3-36 on food intake in humans.|pmid=16285944|doi=10.1053/j.gastro.2005.09.001|volume=129|journal=Gastroenterology|pages=1430–6}}</ref> Insulin also serves as a satiety signal to the brain. The brain detects [[insulin]] in the blood, which indicates that nutrients are being absorbed by cells and a person is getting full. Long-term satiety comes from the fat stored in adipose tissue. Adipose tissue secretes the hormone [[leptin]], and leptin suppresses appetite. Long-term satiety signals from adipose tissue regulates short-term satiety signals.<ref name=Carlson />
====Role of the brain==== The [[brain stem]] can control food intake, because it contains neural circuits that detect hunger and satiety signals from other parts of the body.<ref name=Carlson /> The brain stem’s involvement of food intake has been researched using rats. Rats that have had the motor neurons in the brain stem disconnected from the neural circuits of the cerebral hemispheres (decerebration), are unable to approach and eat food.<ref name=Carlson /> Instead they have to obtain their food in a liquid form. This research shows that the brain stem does in fact play a role in eating.
There are two peptides in the [[hypothalamus]] that produce hunger, [[melanin concentrating hormone]] (MCH) and [[orexin]]. MCH plays a bigger role in producing hunger. In mice, MCH stimulates feeding and a mutation causing the overproduction of MCH led to overeating and obesity.<ref name=MCH>{{cite web|last=Shimada|first=M|title=MCH (Melanin Concentrating Hormone) and MCH-2 Receptor|url=http://www.phoenixbiotech.net/allobesity/Catalog%20Files/MCH%20Section/MCH.html|work=Mice lacking Melanin-Concentrating Hormone are hypophagic and lean.|accessdate=29 April 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090905145154/http://www.phoenixbiotech.net/allobesity/Catalog%20Files/MCH%20Section/MCH.html|archivedate=5 September 2009|df=}}</ref> Orexin plays a greater role in controlling the relationship between eating and sleeping. Other peptides in the hypothalamus that induce eating are neuropeptide Y (NPY) and agouti-related protein (AGRP).<ref name=Carlson />
Satiety in the hypothalamus is stimulated by leptin. Leptin targets the receptors on the arcuate nucleus and suppresses the secretion of MCH and orexin. The arcuate nucleus also contains two more peptides that suppress hunger. The first one is [[cocaine- and amphetamine-regulated transcript]] (CART), the second is α-MSH (α-melanocyte-stimulating hormone).<ref name=Carlson />
==Disorders== {{main|Eating disorder}}
Physiologically, eating is generally triggered by [[Hunger (motivational state)|hunger]], but there are numerous physical and psychological conditions that can affect [[appetite]] and disrupt normal eating patterns. These include [[clinical depression|depression]], food [[allergy|allergies]], ingestion of certain chemicals, [[bulimia]], [[anorexia nervosa]], [[pituitary gland]] malfunction and other [[endocrine]] problems, and numerous other [[illness]]es and [[eating disorder]]s.
A chronic lack of nutritious food can cause various illnesses, and will eventually lead to [[starvation]]. When this happens in a locality on a massive scale, it is considered a [[famine]].
If eating and [[drinking]] is not possible, as is often the case when recovering from [[surgery]], alternatives are [[Route of administration#Enteral|enteral]]<ref name= Feeding>{{cite web|title=Pediatric Feeding Tube |url=https://pediatricfeeding.com/tube-feeding/|publisher=Feeding Clinic of Santa Monica|accessdate=8 July 2013}}</ref> nutrition and [[parenteral nutrition]].<ref>Heisler, Jennifer. "Surgery." About.com. N.p., May–June 2010. Web. 13 Mar. 2013.</ref> ==Other animals== ===Mammals=== {{transcluded section|Mammal#Feeding}} <!-- The references missing when this section is transcluded have been added as list references in reflist --> {{#section-h::Mammal|Feeding}}

'''Elitour''' is the Greek Medical Tourism Council. It is associated with the [[Greek National Tourism Organization]].
Dr Giorgos Patoulis is the President of the council. He is also President of the [[Athens Medical Association]] and the Central Union of Municipalities of Greece. He is a proponent of Greece's thermal natural resources, and says that "Thermal tourism is a dominant lever in the National Health Tourism Strategic Plan."<ref>{{cite news |title=Greece should teach the Greek experience of Well-being' to the world |url=https://www.balkaneu.com/greece-should-teach-the-greek-experience-of-well-being-to-the-world/ |accessdate=12 November 2018 |publisher=Independent Balkan News Agency |date=15 October 2018}}</ref>
Mr. Petros Mamalakis is the General Secretary.
It organised a Health Tourism Day in March 2018.<ref>{{cite news |title=Health Tourism Day - 3rd Health Forum, Saturday 17/3/18 |url=https://news.travelling.gr/2018/03/%CE%B7%CE%BC%CE%B5%CF%81%CE%AF%CE%B4%CE%B1-%CF%84%CE%BF%CF%85%CF%81%CE%B9%CF%83%CE%BC%CE%BF%CF%8D-%CF%85%CE%B3%CE%B5%CE%AF%CE%B1%CF%82-3%CE%BF-forum-%CF%85%CE%B3%CE%B5%CE%AF%CE%B1%CF%82-%CF%83/ |accessdate=12 November 2018 |publisher=Travelling News |date=17 March 2018}}</ref>
It assisted in organising the [[International Medical Travel Journal]] Medical Travel Summit in Athens in May 2018.<ref>{{cite news |title=IMTJ: Greece Can Grow its Medical Tourism Business |url=https://news.gtp.gr/2018/05/23/imtj-greece-grow-medical-tourism-business/ |accessdate=12 November 2018 |publisher=Greek Travel Pages |date=23 May 2018}}</ref> and a Medical Tourism Symposium in November 2018 which was addressed by Giorgos Tzilalas, the General Secretary of Tourism Policy and Development and Mr. G. Giannopoulos the Secretary General of the [[Ministry of Health (Greece)|Ministry of Health]] and was intended to facilitate collective effort with the formulation of a national strategy.<ref>{{cite news |title=Βράβευση του Κ. Στέγγου στο 1ο Συμπόσιο Ιατρικού Τουρισμού! |url=https://money-tourism.gr/vraveysi-k-steggoy-1o-symposio-iatrikoy-toyrismoy/ |accessdate=12 November 2018 |publisher=Money Tourism Greece |date=9 November 2018}}</ref>
The board held a meeting in April 2018, shortly after their election with [[Elena Kountoura]] the Minister of Tourism to coordinate a strategy for the organized development of thematic tourism products.<ref>{{cite news |title=Kountouras - ELITOUR meeting to promote Medical Tourism |url=https://money-tourism.gr/synantisi-kountoura-elitour-gia-tin-proothisi-tou-iatrikou-tourismou/ |accessdate=12 November 2018 |publisher=Money Tourism Greece |date=23 April 2018}}</ref>
It has organised the [[World Institute of Greek Doctors]] in order to mobilise the support of Greek expatriate doctors.<ref>{{cite news |title=Ιατρικός Τουρισμός: Η Ελλάδα έχει τα κλειδιά και θα τα καταφέρει, εκτιμούν ξένες προσωπικότητες |url=https://www.onmed.gr/ygeia-eidhseis/story/367075/iatrikos-toyrismos-h-ellada-exei-ta-kleidia-kai-tha-ta-kataferei-ektimoyn-xenes-prosopikotites |accessdate=12 November 2018 |publisher=OnMed Greece |date=23 May 2018}}</ref>
